item.title: Palabra del día: ‘sagacious’
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en seis artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: El rechazo es la nueva perfección para esta ‘influencer’
item.description: Su meta, acumular 1000 negativas, ha ayudado a otros a lidiar con la frustración.
item.dc:creator: Megan Farokhmanesh

item.title: Word of the Day: sagacious
item.description: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: The Time Has Come for the U.S. to Act in Iran
item.description: It is time for the U.S. to intervene militarily in Iran, at least to deter future killings of protesters.
item.dc:creator: Masih Alinejad

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: UK Seeks Trade With China Without Triggering Trump’s Fury
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer hopes to boost his country’s lagging economy with a trip to Beijing. But he must carefully navigate between two superpowers.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and David Pierson

media:content.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Pool, via Reuters
media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain and Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, attending a meeting in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in 2024.

item.title: All-Night Concerts in War-Ravaged Myanmar
item.description: But the shows, which combine dance, drama and music, are also part of an effort by Myanmar’s military rulers to project a veneer of legitimacy.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Lauren DeCicca

item.description: Phoe Chit’s fans enjoying the performance.
U Chit Myo Htike, known by his stage name Phoe Chit, performing with his zat pwe troupe in Yangon, Myanmar, in January.

item.title: Record Debt in the World’s Richest Nations Threatens Global Growth
item.description: The cost of borrowing is already choking crucial public spending in many developing economies. Now it’s raising broader alarms.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

media:content.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Record-high debt in the United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan risks slowing growth and destabilizing the global economy.

item.title: Corrections: Jan. 27, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Jan. 27, 2026.

item.title: The Social Media Addiction Trials: What to Know
item.description: Landmark trials beginning this week will test a new legal strategy claiming that Meta, TikTok, Snap and YouTube caused personal injury through addictive products.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang

media:content.media:credit: David Gray/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The lawsuits will for the first time put social media companies on the spot for creating harmful products, exposing them to new kinds of liability.

item.title: Social Media Giants Face Landmark Legal Tests on Child Safety
item.description: Starting this week, a series of trials will test a new legal strategy claiming that Meta, TikTok, Snap and YouTube caused personal injury through addictive products.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang

media:content.media:credit: Matt Cardy/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Jury selection is expected to start Tuesday for the first trial in a series of lawsuits that target social media companies with a strategy that had success against tobacco giants.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Economic Fear Running Deep, Times Poll Says
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 27, 2025.

item.title: Trump Holds 2-Hour Meeting With Noem Amid Backlash to Minneapolis Shooting
item.description: The meeting is a sign that the president is concerned about the fallout from the killing of Alex Pretti, who was shot by immigration agents.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, at the White House earlier this month.

item.title: New Video Analysis Reveals Flawed and Fatal Decisions in Shooting of Pretti
item.description: A frame-by-frame assessment of actions by Alex Pretti and the two officers who fired 10 times shows how lethal force came to be used against a target who didn’t pose a threat.
item.dc:creator: Devon Lum, Haley Willis, Alexander Cardia, Dmitriy Khavin and Ainara Tiefenthäler

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Jan. 27, 2026
item.description: This collaboration by Miranda Kany and Tracy Bennett will give you wings.
item.dc:creator: Peter Blair

media:content.media:credit: Jason Connolly/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Round up your wits and step into today’s puzzle.

item.title: Chris Madel Ends Run for Minnesota Governor, Citing Immigration Crackdown
item.description: Chris Madel, a defense lawyer, called the operation “simply a disaster.” His decision comes two days after a second fatal shooting by federal agents in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Pooja Salhotra

media:content.media:credit: Leila Navidi/Star Tribune, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Chris Madel said the immigration crackdown in Minneapolis “has departed so far from the stated goals that it is simply a disaster.”

item.title: Winter Storm Debilitates the South, Encasing Cities in Ice and Snow
item.description: The forecasts had predicted that the storm could be among the worst in a generation to hit the region. By Monday, it was clear that is exactly what happened.
item.dc:creator: LaReeca Rucker and Rick Rojas

media:content.media:credit: William DeShazer for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Some storm damage in Nashville on Sunday. Nashville Electric Service said that as many as 230,000 people were without power at the peak, the largest number of simultaneous power outages in the agency’s history.

item.title: Border Patrol Official Gregory Bovino Is Set to Leave Minnesota
item.description: The Trump administration is planning to move Gregory Bovino, the Border Patrol official leading an aggressive immigration crackdown, out of Minneapolis, officials said. Some protesters in the city expressed cautious relief at the news.
item.dc:creator: Jackeline Luna and Shawn Paik

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: U.S. Border Patrol official Gregory Bovino and other U.S. Border Patrol agents earlier this month in Minneapolis, Minnesota.

item.title: Trump Administration Takes Another Stake in Rare Earth Sector
item.description: The administration announced a $1.6 billion deal with USA Rare Earth. The firm also does business with Cantor Fitzgerald, which is run by the sons of President Trump’s commerce secretary.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

media:content.media:credit: Liam Kennedy for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: “This investment ensures our supply chains are resilient and no longer reliant on foreign nations,” Howard Lutnick, the secretary of commerce, said of the deal.

item.title: After Alex Pretti, Kyle Rittenhouse Is Again a Lightning Rod Online
item.description: After the death of Alex Pretti, some people are posting about a different young man who brought a gun to a protest and the treatment he received from law enforcement agents.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Taylor Pemberton

media:content.media:credit: Grace Ramey/Daily News, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Kyle Rittenhouse has been celebrated on the right as a symbol of Second Amendment rights.

item.title: Trump Briefed on Intelligence Saying Iran’s Government Is Weaker
item.description: Protests that erupted late last year shook elements of the Iranian government, according to the reports.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Vahid Salemi/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: A street in Tehran on Sunday. The reports signal that the Iranian government’s hold on power is at its weakest point since the shah was overthrown in the 1979 revolution.

item.title: Alex Pretti Shooting Poses a Question for the Right: Who’s a Conservative?
item.description: Republicans wrestle with Trump administration positions that seem to contradict their beliefs on gun rights, states’ rights and limited use of federal power.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset

media:content.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mourners at the spot where Alex Pretti was killed by federal agents. Protesters have called for immigration agents to leave.

item.title: Trump Says He Will Raise Tariffs on South Korea to 25%
item.description: President Trump threatened to increase tariffs on South Korean exports, including cars, citing the country’s slow ratification of a trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump on Monday said he would raise tariffs on South Korea.

item.title: F.A.A. Rolls Out Agency Overhaul for Improving Air Safety
item.description: The announcement of a reorganization comes nearly a year after a midair collision killed 67 people and prompted a public outcry for enhancing the security of aviation travel.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Bryan Bedford, the leader of the Federal Aviation Administration, during a hearing at the Capitol last month.

item.title: No Snow Day? In New York City Parks, It Felt Like One.
item.description: Some children skipped remote classes in city schools in favor of activities they felt were more important: sledding and snowball fights.
item.dc:creator: Kaja Andric and Tim Balk

media:content.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Children and families went sledding in Prospect Park in Brooklyn on Monday.

item.title: Trump Changes Course in Minnesota
item.description: Also, large parts of the U.S. are dangerously cold. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gregory Bovino in Minneapolis last week.

item.title: A Year After DC Plane Crash, Concerns About Airport’s Safety Continue
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration says it has reduced traffic in and out of the airport and designed safer routes. Crash victims’ families want more.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly

media:content.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times

item.title: How Does Climate Change Affect Winter Storms?
item.description: A warmer atmosphere has the potential to hold more moisture, which can contribute to heavier precipitation in any season, scientists say.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey

media:content.media:credit: Aristide Economopoulos for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Snow falling in Montclair, N.J., on Sunday.

item.title: What Minneapolis Means for the Country and Its Politics
item.description: Our reporter who spent time in the city weighed in on how the chaos is changing the political landscape.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A memorial in Minneapolis for Alex Pretti, the man killed by federal agents.

item.title: New York City Races to Help Homeless People as Temperatures Plunge
item.description: The weather underscored how vulnerable people are when they do not have a safe place to shelter. At least eight people have died, including several who had a history with the city’s shelter system.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri

media:content.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Temperatures in New York City dropped into the teens and single digits in recent days, creating dangerous conditions for homeless people who live outdoors.

item.title: What to Expect for a Cold NYC Commute: Trains, Buses and Rail
item.description: Mass transit is slowly getting back to normal around the city.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen
item.category: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey

media:content.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: An M.T.A. bus passing Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn on Sunday.

item.title: After Mamdani Nods to ‘Heated Rivalry,’ Library E-Book Downloads Surge
item.description: As a snowstorm arrived, Mayor Zohran Mamdani reminded New Yorkers that they could access the romance series that inspired the TV show through their public library.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: At a Sunday news conference, Mayor Zohran Mamdani mentioned the New York Public Library’s promotion of “Heated Rivalry,” the romance novel that was adapted into a wildly popular TV show.

item.title: Weekly Student News Quiz: Minnesota Killing, Snow Storm, College Football
item.description: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Engle

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Investigation Into Minneapolis Shooting of Alex Pretti Appears Limited
item.description: A use-of-force review is far different than a criminal investigation of the killing of Alex Pretti by Border Patrol agents in Minneapolis.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, Alan Feuer and Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: People gathering Monday in Minneapolis at a memorial for Alex Pretti.

item.title: Border Patrol Official Gregory Bovino Is Set to Leave Minnesota
item.description: The news of Mr. Bovino’s impending departure came hours after President Trump sent his border czar, Tom Homan, to take control of ICE operations in the state.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: U.S. Border Patrol official Gregory Bovino and other U.S. Border Patrol agents earlier this month in Minneapolis, Minnesota.

item.title: Killings in Minneapolis Invert Usual Dynamic Over Policing the Police
item.description: It is far rarer and more difficult for state authorities to try to investigate federal law enforcement officials than the other way around.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage

media:content.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Protesters in Minneapolis gather near where Alex Pretti was killed. It is rare for state and local police to try to investigate federal law enforcement officials.

item.title: Winter Storm Linked to at Least 22 Deaths in the US
item.description: The storm deaths were reported in New York, Tennessee, Louisiana, Kansas, Texas, Massachusetts, Arkansas, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Mississippi, Kentucky and New Jersey, and other deaths were under investigation.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch and Anushka Patil

media:content.media:credit: Liam Kennedy for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Deaths related to the winter storm were reported in multiple states.

item.title: Thomas Fogarty, 91, Who Helped Revolutionize Vascular Surgery, Dies
item.description: Drawing on his love of fly-fishing, he developed a balloon catheter that removes blood clots from patients’ limbs in a minimally invasive way. It has saved millions of lives.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman

media:content.media:credit: Jeff Zelevansky/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Dr. Thomas J. Fogarty in 2000 on receiving the Lemelson-M.I.T. Prize for his work in developing medical technologies. He “single-handedly changed the face of cardiovascular surgery,” a colleague said.

item.title: Alex Pretti Shooting in Minneapolis Went Wrong From the Start, Experts Say
item.description: Law enforcement experts say federal agents deviated from standard practice before and during the shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis, based on videos.
item.dc:creator: Reis Thebault and Maia Coleman

media:content.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: In the moments leading up to the shooting of Alex Pretti in Minneapolis, federal agents had acted in ways that raised serious questions among policing experts.

item.title: Remains of Final Israeli Hostage in Gaza Returned to Israel
item.description: The Israeli government announced on Monday that Israel’s last captive in Gaza had been returned home and that it will allow the Rafah crossing to reopen within the next few days.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling

media:content.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Rafah border crossing with Egypt in October 2023. Israel agreed to allow the crossing to reopen as part of the cease-fire deal struck in October.

item.title: Canada’s Marineland Whales Could Find New Homes in U.S.
item.description: Marineland, a closed aquatic park in Ontario, had threatened to euthanize its whales after the government denied an application to send them to China.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai

media:content.media:credit: Daphné Lemelin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Beluga whales in November at the now-closed Arctic Cove exhibit at Marineland, in Niagara Falls, Canada.

item.title: ¿Qué se siente escalar un rascacielos?
item.description: Alex Honnold, que el domingo subió por un edificio de 508 metros de altura en Taiwán, es parte de un reducido grupo de aventureros conocidos en todo el mundo.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon

media:content.media:credit: I-Hwa Cheng/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: The War in Minnesota Is for Our Phones
item.description: We need to protect our right to carry cameras to document ICE’s violence.
item.dc:creator: Julia Angwin

media:content.media:credit: Associated Press, Getty Images, The New York Times, and Reuters

item.title: Chinese Pandas Leave Japanese Zoo
item.description: As Japan and China feud, an animal long used in Chinese diplomacy has been summoned back home.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni

media:content.media:credit: Issei Kato/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Visitors taking last photos of Xiao Xiao at the Ueno Zoo in Tokyo on Sunday.

item.title: NATO Chief Says Europe Is ‘Dreaming’ if It Thinks It Can Defend Itself Without U.S.
item.description: Mark Rutte, the secretary general of the alliance, told members of the European Parliament that President Trump was “doing a lot of good stuff.”
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman

media:content.media:credit: Nicolas Tucat/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Secretary General Mark Rutte of NATO, right, at the European Parliament in Brussels on Monday.

item.title: Court Affirms Ruling That Alina Habba Served Unlawfully as U.S. Attorney
item.description: The Justice Department lost a bid to challenge a decision that had found Ms. Habba was serving unlawfully as New Jersey’s top federal prosecutor.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich and Tracey Tully

media:content.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Alina Habba, a former personal lawyer to President Trump, is now a senior adviser to Attorney General Pam Bondi and oversees U.S. attorneys across the country.

item.title: Democrats Embrace a Shutdown Fight They Wanted to Avoid
item.description: After a second fatal shooting of a U.S. citizen in Minneapolis, Democrats say public opinion is on their side and they are willing to risk a backlash to counter what they see as police-state tactics.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse

media:content.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis after the shooting of a U.S. citizen on Saturday.

item.title: Bovino Set to Leave Minnesota as Trump Shakes Up Crackdown Leadership
item.description: Gregory Bovino, a Border Patrol official who became a target of fierce criticism, is set to depart as President Trump moves to deflect anger over a second fatal shooting. Mr. Trump’s border czar, Tom Homan, will now direct ICE operations in the state.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times

item.title: Storm’s Death Toll Climbs as Officials Warn of Frigid Cold Ahead
item.description: At least 22 deaths were attributed to the weekend’s snowstorm. More than 700,000 homes and businesses, particularly in the South, remained without power on Monday, and officials said it could take days to restore it.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Andres Kudacki for The New York Times
